7d82ff8b-5528-46e5-9e93-64c7f2603de1.name: Myles Foley
7d82ff8b-5528-46e5-9e93-64c7f2603de1.bio:
I am a researcher dedicated to the intersection of machine learning and computer network defense, with a focus on developing autonomous systems that enhance security in complex environments. My work explores the application of deep reinforcement learning to create intelligent defense agents capable of adapting to various attack strategies. I have designed an end-to-end methodology that visualizes adversarial behavior through state diagrams, allowing for informed intervention points and improved agent performance.

In addition to network defense, I am actively investigating the implications of generative large language models (LLMs) in terms of accountability and copyright issues. My recent research aims to trace the origins of fine-tuned LLMs back to their pre-trained base models, addressing concerns over model theft and harmful content generation. This work is crucial in establishing transparency within the model supply chain.

Furthermore, I have explored the resilience of communication networks in disaster relief scenarios, particularly when faced with compromised drones. By leveraging multi-agent deep reinforcement learning, I have developed strategies that maximize communication bandwidth despite adversarial disruptions. My findings highlight the importance of information-rich observations, expert-guided learning, and reward optimization in enhancing the performance of learning-based agents.

Through my research, I strive to contribute to the development of robust, autonomous systems that can effectively defend against evolving threats in both network security and generative technologies.

226624c4-825d-40b4-81ce-3acc563fb125.name: Chris Hicks
226624c4-825d-40b4-81ce-3acc563fb125.bio:
I am a researcher dedicated to addressing pressing challenges at the intersection of technology, privacy, and public health, particularly in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. My work has focused on developing innovative solutions for contact tracing and immunity passports, emphasizing user privacy and security. I have proposed novel protocols, such as SecureABC, for issuing and verifying antibody certificates while minimizing individual discrimination.

Recognizing the limitations of legacy mobile devices in developing regions, I created an open-source interface for QR code credentials, enabling access to modern identity platforms for economically disadvantaged populations. My research also delves into advanced machine learning techniques, including deep reinforcement learning for network defense and adversarial contextual bandits, where I have developed algorithms that enhance efficiency and performance in complex environments.

I am particularly interested in the implications of machine learning in cybersecurity, exploring the detection of backdoors in deep reinforcement learning agents and the design of autonomous network defense systems. My work aims to bridge the gap between theoretical advancements and practical applications, ensuring that emerging technologies are both effective and equitable. Through my research, I strive to contribute to a safer, more inclusive digital landscape, leveraging my expertise to tackle the multifaceted challenges posed by modern technology.

ff45b210-b6b1-42c1-9bc8-4743efe644e7.name: Kate Highnam
ff45b210-b6b1-42c1-9bc8-4743efe644e7.bio:
I am a researcher dedicated to enhancing cybersecurity through innovative machine learning techniques. My work primarily focuses on detecting and mitigating threats posed by domain generation algorithms (DGAs) used by botnets and malware. I developed a hybrid neural network model, Bilbo, which combines convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks for effective DGA detection. This model has demonstrated superior performance in identifying malicious domains, even in complex scenarios where traditional methods fall short.

In addition to DGA detection, I have explored the intricacies of neural network parameter spaces through my algorithm, GENNI, which visualizes symmetries in neural networks. This work has significant implications for understanding model identifiability and optimization.

My research also delves into causal relationships in cybersecurity through adaptive designs inspired by clinical trials. By conducting controlled honeypot studies, I have been able to identify the impact of specific vulnerabilities on exploitation rates, enhancing our understanding of attack dynamics.

Furthermore, I am investigating the resilience of communication networks in hostile environments, particularly in disaster relief scenarios. By employing multi-agent deep reinforcement learning, I aim to develop strategies that maximize communication bandwidth despite adversarial challenges. My approach integrates expert techniques with learning-based agents, leading to improved performance in network resilience.

Overall, my research combines theoretical insights with practical applications, striving to advance the field of cybersecurity through innovative methodologies and robust solutions.

ad194c3d-ff7f-4219-af7f-4b17c2313d7a.name: Vasilios Mavroudis
ad194c3d-ff7f-4219-af7f-4b17c2313d7a.bio:
I am a researcher dedicated to addressing the complexities of modern financial systems, cybersecurity, and privacy through innovative methodologies and technologies. My work spans a range of topics, including market manipulation in equity exchanges, where I explore mechanical arbitrage techniques and propose technical solutions to enhance market fairness. I have also investigated the challenges of temporal fairness in order-matching systems, introducing the concept of ε-fairness to ensure equitable treatment of market participants.

In the realm of cybersecurity, I focus on the adversarial aspects of machine learning, particularly in deep reinforcement learning and out-of-distribution sample detection. My research on webpage fingerprinting and the detection of backdoors in reinforcement learning policies aims to bolster the security of online systems against sophisticated attacks. Additionally, I have developed Snappy, a novel blockchain payment solution that addresses latency issues while ensuring safe and fast transactions.

My commitment to inclusivity is evident in my work on legacy mobile devices, where I designed a QR code interface to facilitate access to modern identity platforms for underserved populations. I also delve into the intersection of technology and privacy in retail environments, advocating for balanced approaches that respect consumer rights while enabling personalized experiences.

Overall, my research is driven by a desire to create fair, secure, and efficient systems that can withstand the challenges posed by technological advancements and adversarial actors.
